Events

As we have already noted a collection of some or all of the outcomes of an experiment is called an event. So an event is a subset of the sample space. For example, if we throw a 6-sided die then the sample space is \(\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}\) and two possible events are

  • a score of 3 or more, represented by the set: \(\{3, 4, 5, 6\}\)
  • a score which is even, represented by the set: \(\{2, 4, 6\}\).

Example

Two coins are thrown. List the ordered outcomes for the event when just one Tail is obtained.

Solution

\(\{HT, TH\}\). Note that here the order does matter, i.e. \(TH\) is distinct from \(HT\).
